For more info, go to: https://www.ebparks.org/about/stewardship/water/cyanobacteria_(blue_green_algae)_updates.htm
The 2021 routine monitoring results are provided below:
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
On 7/27/21 and 7/28/21, adjustments were made to the Hypolimnetic Oxygenation System to better direct oxygen flow into the deepest regions of the lake. Unfortunately, the system ran out of oxygen before the effectiveness of those adjustments could be tested. 7/28/21, very fine specks and small clumps of Dolichospermum-type, Woronichinia-type, and Aphanizomenon-type cyanobacteria were observed suspended throughout the water column throughout the lake, with the heaviest accumulations observed at the dam/spillway.

On 7/19/21, very fine specks of Microcystis-type, Dolichospermum-type, and Woronichinia-type cyanobacteria were observed suspended throughout the water column at the swim beach, with the heaviest accumulations observed along the swim ropes. A sample was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in 1.63 ppb.

On 7/15/21, like last week, very fine specks of Microcystis-type and Woronichinia-type cyanobacteria were observed suspended throughout the water column at the swim beach and throughout the entire lake.

On 7/7/21, very fine specks of Microcystis-type and Woronichinia-type cyanobacteria were observed suspended throughout the water column at the swim beach, dam, and throughout the lake. A sample from the dam was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in a non-detect.

On 6/29/21, very small specks of Microcystis-type and Woronichinia-type cyanobacteria were observed suspended throughout the water column at the swim beach and throughout the lake. A sample was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in 1.06 ppb.

On 6/21/21, clumps and clusters of Aphanizomenon-type and Woronichinia-type cyanobacteria were observed suspended throughout the water column at the swim beach. A sample was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in a non-detect.

On 6/14/21, large accumulations of Aphanizomenon-type and Woronichinia-type cyanobacteria with some Dolichospermum-type cyanobacteria were observed accumulating on the swim ropes around the swim beach. High biomass of the same cyanobacteria species were observed throughout the entire lake, with specks and clumps densely suspended in the water column. A sample from the swim ropes was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in 0.14 ppb. Swimming is still not allowed.

Results from last week downgraded Lake Anza to a Caution on 6/7/21. On 6/8/21, specks and clumps of Aphanizomenon-type, Dolichospermum-type, Woronichinia-type, and Microcystis-type cyanobacteria were observed suspended throughout the lake. A sample from the swim beach was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in a non-detect.

On 6/2/21, specks and clumps of Aphanizomenon-type, Dolichospermum-type, Woronichinia-type, and Microcystis-type cyanobacteria were observed suspended throughout the water column at the dam and swim beach. Large accumulations of the same cyanobacteria types were observed accumulating along the swim rope lines and getting trapped in the weeds growing in the shallows. Some patches of blue-green discoloration were also observed at both locations. A sample from the swim beach was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis Strip Test Kits, resulting in a non-detect. On 6/3/21 specks and clumps of the same cyanobacteria types were observed throughout the entire lake.

On 5/26/21, specks and clumps of Aphanizomenon-type, Dolichospermum-type, and Microcystis-type cyanobacteria were observed suspended throughout the water column at throughout the entire lake. Large accumulations of the same cyanobacteria types were observed accumulating along the swim rope lines. A sample from the swim beach was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in a non-detect. On 5/27/21, specks of Dolichospermum-type and Microcystis-type cyanobacteria were observed suspended in the water column at the swim beach. Samples were tested for Anatoxin-A and Cylindrospermopsin, using Abraxis Strip Test Kits, resulting in non-detects. 

On 5/17/21, specks and clumps of Aphanizomenon-type, Dolichospermum-type, and Microcystis-type cyanobacteria were observed suspended throughout the water column at the swim beach. Large accumulations of the same cyanobacteria types with some turquoise clumps were observed accumulating in lines along the shore of the swim beach. A sample from the swim beach was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in 0.34 ppb.

The 2021 routine monitoring results are provided below:
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
On 7/27/21, very few small specks of Microcystis-type cyanobacteria were observed suspended in the water column at the boat launch. No visible cyanobacteria were observed at the East and West swim beaches. A sample from the boat launch was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis Strip Test Kit, resulting in a non-detect.

On 7/20/21, small specks of Microcystis-type cyanobacteria were observed suspended in the water column at the marina. Oscillatoria-type cyanobacteria were observed in a sheen accumulating on the swim ropes on the south end of the west beach. A sample from the marina was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in 0.82 ppb. Samples from the raw intake of the drinking water plant and treated water from Building 13 were also tested, using Abraxis CAAS, both resulting in a non-detects.

On 7/12/21, small specks of Oscillatoria-type cyanobacteria were observed suspended in the water column at the East and West beaches. No visible cyanobacteria were observed at the boat launch nor at Hetch Hetchy Group Camp. Samples from the boat launch, East beach, and West beach were tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis Strip Test Kits, resulting in non-detects. 

On 7/6/21, small specks of Microcystis-type cyanobacteria were observed suspended throughout the water column at the boat launch. Oscillatoria-type or Limnoraphis-type cyanobacteria were observed in scum accumulating on the swim ropes on the south end of the west beach. A sample from the boat launch was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in 17.71 ppb. On 7/9/21, specks of Microcystis-type and Dolichospermum-type cyanobacteria were observed at the Hetch Hetchy Group Camp and the boat launch. No visible cyanobacteria were observed at the East beach. Few specks of Oscillatoria-type cyanobacteria were observed in scum accumulating on the swim ropes on the southern end of the West beach. A sample from the Hetch Hetchy Group Camp was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis Strip Tests, resulting in 5 ppb. Samples from the boat launch, East beach, and West beach were tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis Strip Test Kits, all resulting in non-detects. Due to the mixed toxin test results, Del Valle will remain at a Caution pending re-evaluation next week.

On 6/28/21, small specks of cyanobacteria were observed at the swim beaches, but denser small specks of Dolichospermum-type cyanobacteria were observed suspended throughout the water column at the boat launch. A sample from the boat launch was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in a 3.78 ppb.

On 6/22/21, small clumps of Dolichospermum-type and Microcystis-type cyanobacteria were observed at the boat launch. More clumps of Dolichospermum-type cyanobacteria were observed at the marina. A sample from the boat launch was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in a non-detect. Samples from the raw drinking water intake to the drinking water treatment plant and treated water from building 13 were also collected. We split the samples and sent samples to Bend Genetics lab for analysis of four cyanotoxins, and we tested both sites for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in a non-detects.

The 2021 routine monitoring results are provided below:
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
On 7/26/21, few clusters of Oscillatoria-type or Limnoraphis-type cyanobacteria were observed suspended in the water column at the swim beach. The same cyanobacteria type(s) were observed in clusters and surface level swirls at the south end of the lake. The same cyanobacteria type(s) were also observed Northwest dock, where the water was visibly turbid.

On 7/19/21, specks of Oscillatoria-type cyanobacteria were observed suspended in the water column at the swim beach. A sample from the swim beach was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in a non-detect. On 7/21/21, small clumps and specks of Oscillatoria-type cyanobacteria were observed accumulating around and suspended in the water column at the Northwest dock.

On 7/12/21, very few tiny specks of Oscillatoria-type cyanobacteria were observed suspended in the water column at the swim beach and south end. A sample from the south end was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in 0.04 ppb. Advisory signage has been taken down around the lake.

On 7/6/21, very few tiny specks of Dolichospermum-type and Oscillatoria-type cyanobacteria were observed suspended in the water column at the swim beach and south end. A sample from the swim beach was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in 0.03 ppb.

On 6/28/21 and 6/29/21, the lake was treated with Pak 27 and Alum to reduce cyanobacteria, algae, and the nutrients they require for growth. Specks of Oscillatoria-type, Dolichospermum-type, Microcystis-type, and Woronichinia-type cyanobacteria were observed during both days of treatment. On 6/30/21, no visible cyanobacteria were observed at the swim beach, ADA dock, south end, or Northwest Dock. A sample from the ADA dock was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in 0.04 ppb.

On 6/23/21, very fine specks of Aphanizomenon-type and Dolichospermum-type cyanobacteria were observed suspended throughout the water column at the Northwest dock. No visible cyanobacteria were observed at the swim beach. A sample from the Northwest dock was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in a non-detect. Next Monday and Tuesday, we plan on treating the lake with Pak 27 to reduce the cyanobacteria and then Alum to reduce the phosphorus that feeds the cyanobacteria.

As a reminder, on 6/10/21 and 6/11/21 an aquatic harvester was deployed to remove filamentous weeds throughout the lake. Despite its efforts, there are still dense accumulations of filamentous algae and sago pond weed throughout the lake, worse on the South end of the lake. On 6/15/21, very fine specks of Microcystis-type and Aphanizomenon-type cyanobacteria were observed suspended throughout the water column at the swim beach and at the south end of the lake. A sample from the swim beach was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in 0.3 ppb. Next week, we plan on treating the lake with either Pak 27 or GreenClean to reduce the cyanobacteria and then treated with Phoslock to reduce phosphorus which is a nutrient that feeds the cyanobacteria. Swimming is still not allowed due to E. coli issues.

On 6/10/21, an aquatic harvester started removing filamentous weeds (primarily sago pond weed). The Harvester is working again on 6/11/21. Next week, we plan on treating the lake with either Pak 27 or GreenClean to reduce the cyanobacteria and then Phoslock to reduce the phosphorus that feeds the cyanobacteria.

On 6/7/21, very fine specks of Microcystis-type and Aphanizomenon-type cyanobacteria were observed suspended throughout the water column at the swim beach and at the south end of the lake. At both locations, some clumps of cyanobacteria were observed stuck in dense growths of filamentous algae and weeds. A sample from the swim beach was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in 0.43 ppb. 

On 6/1/21, specks and clumps of Microcystis-type and Aphanizomenon-type cyanobacteria were observed suspended throughout the water column at the swim beach and at the south end of the lake. At both locations, some clumps of cyanobacteria were observed stuck in dense growths of filamentous algae and weeds.

On 5/24/21, specks and clumps of Aphanizomenon-type cyanobacteria were observed densely suspended throughout the water column at the swim beach, the ADA Dock, and at the south end of the lake. At all locations, clumps of cyanobacteria were stuck in dense growths of filamentous algae. A sample from the swim beach was tested for?Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in 0.06 ppb.

The 2021 routine monitoring results are provided below:
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
On 7/28/21, light green paint chip-like flakes of Microcystis-type cyanobacteria were observed around the rocks by the fishing pier.

On 7/20/21, high winds made observation and sampling difficult around the rocks by the fishing pier. No visible cyanobacteria was observed. A sample was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in 0.09 ppb.

On 7/7/21, small clumps of Microcystis-type cyanobacteria were observed suspended in the water column around the rocks by the fishing pier. Due to similar visual conditions as last week, a sample was not tested this week.

On 6/29/21, small clumps of Microcystis-type cyanobacteria were observed around the rocks by the fishing pier. A sample was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in greater than 50 ppb.  

On 6/21/21, few small specks of Microcystis-type cyanobacteria were observed around the rocks by the fishing pier. A sample was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in 1.38 ppb.  

On 6/14/21, few small specks of Dolichospermum-type cyanobacteria were observed around the rocks by the fishing pier. A sample was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in 7.25 ppb.  

On 6/11/21, small specks were observed and collected, but no cyanobacteria were observed under the microscope. Abraxis Strip tests were performed on both Monday’s and Friday’s samples Monday’s result was greater than 10ppb and Friday’s result was non-detect. Big Break posted a Danger advisory on 6/11/21. 

On 6/7/21, small specks of Dolicospermum-type and Microcystis-type cyanobacteria were observed around the rocks by the fishing pier. A sample was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in greater than 50 ppb.  

On 6/2/21, no visible cyanobacteria were observed around the rocks by the fishing pier.

On 5/25/21, no visible cyanobacteria were observed around the rocks by the fishing pier. A sample was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in 0.04 ppb.

Klamath Basin Monitoring Program conducts routine monitoring of the Klamath Basin for cyanobacteria and cyanotoxins but due to Covid-19 restrictions, some monitoring activities may be different this year. In the Basin, cyanobacteria blooms typically occur between June and October. When water testing indicates that reservoir and river conditions exceed public health recommendations for cyanotoxins, the area is posted with a health advisory sign.

RESULTS:

6/29/2021: Sampling upstream in Copco Reservoir detected microcystins above the CAUTION trigger level. According the Klamath Basin Monitoring Program agreement, it is protocol to post CAUTION two sites below such detections.

6/8/2021: Microcystins were not detected; no postings.

5/11/21: Microcystins were not detected; no postings.
